isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 2000 4000 and 8000 MODELS BUILT OCTOBER 1, 1998 AND AFTER - ALLISON WT TRANSMISSION WITH WTEC III ELECTRONIC CONTROLS - TROUBLESHOOTING - GENERAL TROUBLESHOOTING

svcprocinfo.para: The symptoms listed in this section relate to specific events rather than specific diagnostic codes. It is still a necessary first step to read (and note) any active or inactive diagnostic codes.

step1.para: Perform the following checks. If no defects are found, proceed to Step 2.

step2.para: Check vehicle starting system cables and wires for clean, tight connections. Check connection at B+ terminal of crank motor solenoid for clean, tight connection.

step1.para: Check ECU battery and ignition voltages and ECU grounds by performing test ECU and Shift Selector Power and Ground Circuits, Table 3.

step2.para: If battery and ignition voltage to ECU are to specifications and the ground circuits check good, proceed to Step 3.
If defects were noted in battery, ignition or ground circuits to ECU, correct defects and retest start system.
If neutral start system checks good, proceed to Step 4.
If defects were noted in neutral start system, correct defects and test for proper engine starting.

step1.para: Check the Shift Selector harness circuitry by performing test Selector Harness Circuitry, Table 5. (The shift selector may not be communicating properly to the ECU that the shift selector is in the neutral position.)

step2.para: If shift selector circuits check good, go to Step 5.
If defects are noted in shift circuits, correct condition and test for proper engine starting.

step1.para: Check the Shift Selector operation using an electronic service tool. If an electronic service tool is not available, and the shift selector circuits checked good (Step 4), replace the shift selector.
If the no-start condition is still present after performing steps 1 through 5, have an Allison dealer continue the diagnosis.

svcsubproc.title: CHECK TRANS Light Will Not Go Out at Startup
svcsubproc.para: The "Check Trans" light should be illuminated when the key is turned to the on position and then go out when the vehicle is started. If a diagnostic code is registered because of a condition detected by the ECU that will "inhibit" transmission operation, the Check Trans light should illuminate (refer to diagnostic code chart for those codes that cause the Check Trans light to illuminate).

step1.para: Determine if transmission operation is inhibited.

step2.para: If transmission operation is inhibited and diagnostic code is present, perform diagnostics as indicated by the code.
If transmission is not inhibited, refer to test, Check Trans Light and Circuits,Table 7.

svcsubproc.title: CHECK TRANS Warning Light Does Not Illuminate During Startup
svcsubproc.para: Refer to test Check Trans Light and Circuits,Table 7.

svcsubproc.title: Panel Light Dimmer Does Not Control Electronic Shifter Backlight Intensity
svcsubproc.para: Refer to test Panel Light Feed and Backlight Circuits, Table 8.

svcsubproc.title: Vehicle Backup Lights or Reverse Warning Does Not Function
svcsubproc.para: If power to the backup lights is not present at connector (13)/pin J4 refer to test , Backup Light Relay and Circuits, Table 9.

svcsubproc.title: Vehicle Speedometer Fails To Operate
svcsubproc.para: If the speedometer fails to operate (tachometer operates normally) and the input signal is suspected, check for diagnostic codes from the ECU first.

step1.para: If no codes are present, refer to test J1708 Communications Link, Table 4, speedometer signal ECU to ECM.
If codes are present refer to Troubleshooting With Diagnostic Codes.

svcsubproc.title: If Transmission Will Not Go Into "Lockup" Mode Or Transmission Retarder Will Not Engage On Vehicles Equipped With ABS Brake System
svcsubproc.para:
If no diagnostic codes are present, check the ABS interface circuit by performing test Torque Converter Lock Drop Circuitry for ABS Brake System,
Table 10.

svcsubproc.title: Two-Speed Axle Will Not Shift (Air Operated)
svcsubproc.para: The two-speed axle range is controlled the WTEC III electronic control system by applying (or removing) voltage to the axle solenoid, which is a normally closed solenoid. Without voltage applied, the axle solenoid is closed (no air applied to axle) and the axle will operate in low range. When voltage is applied to the solenoid, the solenoid energizes and air pressure through the solenoid causes the axle to shift to the high range.
If the two-speed axle fails to cycle between ranges when commanded and the transmission output speed is within the programmed range, refer to test Two-Speed Axle (Air Operated), Table 11.

svcsubproc.title: Two-Speed Axle Will Not Shift (Electric Operated)
svcsubproc.para: The two-speed axle range is controlled by the WTEC III electronic control system applying and removing voltage to the axle shift motor high and low speed motor windings. When low range is selected, power will be applied to the low speed winding provided the transmission output speed is within the programmed range.
If the two-speed axle fails to cycle between ranges when commanded and the transmission output speed is within the programmed range, refer to test Two-Speed Axle (Electric Operated), Table 12.

svcsubproc.title: Exhaust Brake Will Not Function
svcsubproc.para: Exhaust brake application is controlled by the WTEC III electronic control system which applies (or removes) voltage to the engine brake relay which signal the ECM that it is OK to apply or remove voltage to the exhaust brake relay which then controls the exhaust brake air solenoid. This solenoid is a normally closed solenoid, and without voltage applied, the exhaust brake air solenoid is closed (exhaust brake not applied). When voltage is applied to the solenoid, the solenoid energizes and air pressure through the solenoid causes the exhaust brake to operate.
If the exhaust brake does not activate with the exhaust brake switch in the on position, perform test Exhaust Brake, Table 13.

svcsubproc.title: Hydraulic Retarder Will Not Function
svcsubproc.para: Hydraulic Retarder application is controlled by the WTEC III electronic control system. This is done by energizing the accumulator solenoid valve and modulating the H solenoid.
If the hydraulic retarder will not function when the request switch is "on" and the transmission output speed is above 350 rpm, perform test Hydraulic Retarder,Table 14.
